}} 'Franz Kafka' }} (3 July 1883 â 3 June 1924) was a German-language
writer of novels and short stories, regarded by critics as one of the most
influential authors of the 20th century. Kafka strongly influenced genres
such as existentialism. Most of his works, such as "" ("The Metamorphosis"),
{{lang|de|[[The Trial|Der Process]]}} (The Trial), and {{lang|de|[[The Castle
(novel)|Das Schloss]]}} (The Castle), are filled with the themes and archetypes
of alienation, physical and psychological brutality, parentâchild conflict,
characters on a terrifying quest, labyrinths of bureaucracy, and mystical
transformations.

Kafka was born into a middle-class, German-speaking Jewish family in Prague,
then part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. At his lifetime, most of Prague
population spoke Czech and the division between Czech and German speaking people
was a tangible reality, as both groups were strengthening their national
identity. Jewish community often found itself in between the two sentiments,
naturally raising questions about a place to which one belongs. Kafka himself
was fluent in both languages, considering German his mother tongue.

Kafka trained as a lawyer and, after completing his legal education, obtained
employment with an insurance company. He began to write short stories in his
spare time. For the rest of his life, he complained about the little time he had
to devote to what he came to regard as his calling. He regretted having to
devote so much attention to his {{lang|de|Brotberuf}} ("day job", literally
"bread job"). Kafka preferred to communicate by letter; he wrote hundreds of
letters to family and close female friends, including his father, his fiancÃ©e
Felice Bauer, and his youngest sister Ottla. He had a complicated and troubled
relationship with his father that had a major effect on his writing. He also
suffered conflict over being Jewish, feeling that it had little to do with him,
although critics argue that it influenced his writing.

Only a few of Kafka's works were published during his lifetime: the story
collections {{lang|de|[[Contemplation (Kafka)|Betrachtung]]}} (Contemplation)
and {{lang|de|[[A Country Doctor (collection)|Ein Landarzt]]}} (A Country
Doctor), and individual stories (such as "") in literary magazines. He prepared
the story collection {{lang|de|[[A Hunger Artist (collection)|Ein
HungerkÃ¼nstler]]}} (A Hunger Artist) for print, but it was not published until
after his death. Kafka's unfinished works, including his novels {{lang|de|Der
Process}}, {{lang|de|Das Schloss}} and {{lang|de|[[Amerika (novel)|Amerika]]}}
(also known as {{lang|de|Der Verschollene}}, The Man Who Disappeared), were
published posthumously, mostly by his friend Max Brod, who ignored Kafka's wish
to have the manuscripts destroyed. Albert Camus and Jean-Paul Sartre are among
the writers influenced by Kafka's work; the term Kafkaesque has entered the
English language to describe surreal situations like those in his writing.
